chapter.htmlHeader: What are the consequences of domestic violence and abuse?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Domestic violence and abuse is a serious health and criminal issue that can adversely affect the physical and mental health of the person being abused [DH, 2017].
    • Physical impacts include [CDC, 2017; DH, 2017]:
      • Direct results of physical violence, including bruising, stab wounds, broken bones, burns, traumatic brain injury, back or pelvic pain, headaches, and death. 
      • Long-term physical health sequlae, including asthma, bladder and kidney infections, circulatory disorders, cardiovascular disease, fibromyalgia, gastrointestinal disorders, long-term pain, central nervous system disorders, joint disease, and migraines. These occur as a result of the impact of domestic violence and abuse on the cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, endocrine, and immune systems through chronic stress or other mechanisms.
    • Reproductive impacts include [CDC, 2017; DH, 2017]:
      • Gynecological disorders (including pelvic pain and sexual dysfunction), pelvic inflammatory disease, sexually transmitted infections (including HIV/AIDS), delayed prenatal care, pregnancy complications (such as miscarriage, maternal death, premature birth, babies with low birthweight, and stillbirth), antenatal and postnatal mental health disorders, and unintended pregnancy.
    • Psychological impacts include [CDC, 2017; DH, 2017]:
      • Anxiety, depression, eating disorders, symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), antisocial behavior (including increased likelihood of engaging in high-risk sexual behaviour and increased likelihood of misusing drugs, alcohol, or prescribed anti-depressants), self-harming, suicidal ideation or attempting suicide, anger, guilt, low self-esteem and confidence, inability to trust others (especially in intimate relationships), fear of intimacy, emotional detachment, feelings of dependency, loss of hope, feelings of isolation, sleep disturbances, and flashbacks.
    • With the exception of gender-specific impacts on women (such as gynaecological problems), the impacts for men and women are similar. However, for men, severe physical violence is less likely and severe depression is more likely, especially in older men [DH, 2017].
  • Domestic violence and abuse in which a parent is abused with children in the household is the most frequently reported form of trauma for children [NICE, 2014].
    • Children living in households where there is domestic violence and abuse can be significantly harmed by neglect that may result, in addition to being exposed to, or being involved in, the abuse [DH, 2017].
    • Exposure to domestic violence and abuse affects the mental, emotional, and psychological health of the child and their social and educational development. It also increases their likelihood of experiencing, or becoming perpetrators of, domestic violence and abuse as adults, and exposes them directly to physical harm [NICE, 2014; DH, 2017; RCN, 2017]. In a research study conducted by CAADA (Co-ordinated Action Against Domestic Abuse) [CAADA, 2014]:
      • 62% of children exposed to domestic violence and abuse were also directly harmed (physically, emotionally, or neglected) as well as witnessing the abuse of a parent. In 91% of cases, the direct harm was perpetrated by the same person as the domestic abuse (mainly the child's father or their mother’s male partner).
      • In addition to other impacts, 52% of children had behavioural problems, 39% had difficulties adjusting at school, and 60% felt responsible for negative events.
      • 25% of both boys and girls exposed to domestic violence and abuse exhibited abusive behaviours themselves, most frequently towards their mother or sibling (and rarely towards the main perpetrator of the domestic violence and abuse). Children were more likely to show abusive behaviours after exposure to the domestic violence and abuse had ended. 
    • There is a strong association between domestic violence and abuse and direct child maltreatment. See the CKS topic on Child maltreatment - recognition and management for more information.
  • Domestic violence and abuse results in huge costs to the NHS and is a challenge to healthcare services in the UK.
    • According to a report from Lancaster University, domestic violence and abuse cost the UK an estimated £15.7 billion in 2008. This included [Walby, 2009]:
      • Over £9.9 billion in human and emotional costs.
      • Over £3.8 billion in costs to the criminal justice system, civil legal services, healthcare, social services, housing, and refuges.
      • Over £1.9 billion in costs to the economy (based on time off work for injuries).
    • The physical and psychological effects of domestic violence and abuse on the victim’s health were estimated to cost the NHS £1.7 billion in 2009, an increase of £500 million since 2004 [BMA, 2014].
